We hear a lot these days about post traumatic stress disorder, or PTSD.
It can lead veterans to substance abuse, violence, even suicide.

Our story comes from Taki Telonidis of the Western Folk Life Center.

It's Friday afternoon, and like he does every week, Cal Bench, a Vietnam vet, is here early, gathering firewood for the ceremony that will start in a few hours.
I went into the service at 18, I went to Vietnam at 19.
And I had no idea how it would change or affect you mentally.
The concept that I would carry that around forever was just hard.
But I just never had any place to turn.
I came here and I was given a blessing.
Cal started coming to these sweats in 2005 to cope with anxieties related to his combat experience.
He found relief in the sweat, as well as a spiritual connection that's kept him coming back.
This VA is one of just a handful in the country that offers them.
A sweat is a ceremony conducted by a Native American spiritual leader in a dome-shaped structure, or lodge.
Sweats are common in Indian country.
It's healing right down to the core of that veteran.
Arnold Thomas is a medicine man from the Shoshone Paiute tribe and has training in social work and chaplaincy.
He has conducted the veteran sweats at the VA since 2004.
When they've been overseas in combat, there's a part of them that is left there.
So when we had the ceremonies, there are certain prayer songs that I offer and make that effort to bring their spirit back home.
Over the years, these ceremonies, originally intended for Native American vets, have drawn more and more non-natives, men and women from several wars - Vietnam, the Gulf War, Afghanistan and Iraq.
And while the sweats aren't a good fit for every vet who tries them, there's a core group who have added these ceremonies to their medical and psychological treatments.
The VA has taken note of their benefits and in February, moved the sweats from the substance abuse program to chaplain services, so they'd be more widely available to vets with PTSD.
Looking at the astounding rates of suicides within the military over the last few years, what I'm reminded is all people have the ability to reason, unless they're grieving.
